chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: **9.1a** The definition of net present value will be used to address this question.

**Net present value** is the value of a cash flow stream that is discounted to the present. The present value is calculated by considering the amount of money that could be earned by investing the cash flow stream for a certain period, then subtracting the cost of the investment. The result is the present value of the cash flow stream. NPV is used to help companies make decisions about whether to invest. According to the NPV rule, a firm should **accept all positive net present value projects and reject all negative net present value ones**. When comparing the worth of a project to the initial investment, the net present value (NPV) criterion is applied. A project with a positive net present value is worth more today than it was when it was first invested, while one with a negative net present value is worth less today. The NPV rule is used in business to **assess which projects should be pursued and which should be abandoned**.
**9.1b**  In this question, we are asked to explain what we think it signifies if an investment has a net present value of $1,000.

This means that the investment is projected to bring in $1,000 more than it costs. In other words, the NPV is the amount of money the investment is expected to bring in, given the current state of the market and other relevant factors. This number can be helpful in making decisions about whether to invest in something. However, it's important to note that NPV is not the only factor that should be considered when making investment decisions. Additionally, net present value is **not always a reliable indicator of future performance**. So, always consult other sources of information before making a decision. Hence, NPV does not take into account taxes or other costs associated with the investment.
In this question, we have been asked about what the net present value rule is.  It has also been asked what a Net Present Value of $\$1,000$ implies.

The object of capital budgeting is to create value for the stockholders. This is what financial management is all about. There are many ways in which the desirability of an investment can be ascertained by the manager. One of the most important methods is the **net present value** of an investment.  

The net present value as the name suggests is the difference between two variables. These are the cost of acquiring the project and the present value of the future cash flows generated from that project.

Before understanding what the net present value rule is, it is important to understand the concept of present value. 

The **present value** is the value of the future stream of cash flows in the present time if a rate of return is given. Thus, the present value and the future value are related. This relation is depicted in the following formula:

$$\text{PV}=\frac{\text{FV}_t}{(1+r)^t}$$

where $\text{PV}$ is the present value,

$\text{FV}_t$ is the future value in the $t^{\text{th}}$ year,

$r$ is the expected rate of return, and

$t$ is the time (in years)

## Requirement 1a. 

As we have discussed above, it is the job of the financial manager to determine the two variables i.e. the cost and the future cash flows. 

The future cash flow stream is obviously an estimate, so this represents the element of risk. Once such estimates are made and the cost of the project ascertained, the difference between the costs and estimates is calculated. 

if the resultant difference gives a **negative result** i.e. $\text{NPV}<0$, it signifies that **no value is added** by the project. This will also have a negative impact on the earnings per share. So, it will not be worth investing in such a project.

On the other hand, if the resultant difference gives a positive result i.e. $\text{NPV}>0$, it signifies that a value is added by the project. This will not have a negative impact on the earnings per share. So, it will be worth investing in such a project.

This rule of when to invest and when not to invest is the **Net Present Value Rule.**

## Requirement 1b. 

 If the $\text{NPV}$ of a particular investment is $\$1,000$, this implies that the difference between the cost of this investment and the sum of the respective present values of the cash flow stream generated by this investment is one thousand dollars. 

Thus this venture will be a profitable one as this investment is adding value to the kitty of the investors.    

If the $\text{NPV}$ rule is applied, $\text{NPV}=\$1,000$ implies the investment is **worth putting money in.**
